llm.feedback: Actionable edits to upgrade to world-class: (1) sharpen the causal chain from policy to price with first-principles cost-driver logic and anchor every link to the source numbers (DOE/EPA standards and the Biden rule add about a +$1,500 per system uplift, a baseline 15-year replacement cost from ~$5,000 to ~ $13,000–$14,000, and R-454B scarcity driving design and installation costs); (2) foreground 0–3 week catalysts and the market’s near‑term reaction function: concrete policy actions or reversals, refrigerant‑supply news, and installers’ labor‑safety adjustments, with the expected price and installation‑volume response; (3) codify invalidation triggers: meaningful policy rollback or meaningful delay beyond the Jan 1, 2025 implement date; (4) adopt a tight, first‑principles framing of cost structure (input costs, regulatory compliance) to justify why costs remain elevated even if some drivers wobble; (5) add a near‑term scenario structure (base/bear/bull) and a concise monitoring checklist (refrigerant availability/prices, DOE/EPA announcements, installation-cost trajectory) without speculating beyond the source; (6) enforce numeric discipline by citing LLN6N4H3Z with each factual claim and reconcile any conflicting interpretations since all sources are the same piece; (7) keep the key near‑term levels explicit: +$1,500 uplift, ~$13k–$14k replacement price, and R‑454B scarcity, as the flywheel for sentiment and decisions.
